model_completion: Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus, which is the muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach. The main cause of esophagitis is acid reflux. When food or liquid travels upward from the stomach into the esophagus, a person may experience symptoms like heartburn, chest pain and regurgitation. Other causes include gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), eosinophilic esophagitis and medication side effects.

The most common symptom of esophagitis is a burning or painful sensation in the chest, throat or upper abdomen. A person with esophagitis may also experience difficulty swallowing, heartburn and regurgitation of food. In severe cases, esophagitis can lead to ulcers, bleeding and perforation of the esophagus.

The most common symptom of esophagitis is a burning sensation in the chest and throat, which is often accompanied by difficulty swallowing. A health care provider will ask the patient about his or her symptoms and then perform a physical exam. If the health care provider suspects esophagitis, he or she will order tests such as an endoscopy, which involves inserting a thin tube with a camera into the esophagus to look for abnormalities, or an upper gastrointestinal (GI) series, which uses x-rays to produce images of the esophagus, stomach and small intestine.

Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus, which is the muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach. The most common cause of esophagitis is acid reflux, but there are several other causes, including medications and infections. Symptoms include a burning sensation in the chest and throat, as well as difficulty swallowing.

The most common treatment for esophagitis is a prescription antacid medication. A variety of antacids are available, and each has different side effects. These include diarrhea, constipation, stomach pain and nausea. Antacids can also interact with other medications, so patients should tell their doctors about any medications they are currently taking.

It is important to avoid foods and drinks that irritate the esophagus. Avoiding spicy, acidic or fried foods may help to prevent esophagitis. Additionally, people with GERD should avoid eating large meals, especially before bedtime. Drinking alcohol and smoking are also known to irritate the esophagus and can increase the risk of developing esophagitis.

Dysentery is a condition that causes severe diarrhea, often with blood in the stool. A person may also experience abdominal pain and fever. Symptoms of dysentery usually appear two to five days after exposure.

Dysentery is typically diagnosed with a medical history and physical exam. A health care professional will ask about the patient's symptoms and examine the abdomen to check for tenderness or pain. Blood tests may also be performed to check for signs of infection, such as an elevated white blood cell count. In some cases, a sample of stool may be sent to a laboratory for testing to determine if there is an infection or parasite present.

Dysentery is a condition that causes severe diarrhea, often with blood in the stool. A person may also experience abdominal pain and fever. The treatment of dysentery will depend on the cause, but usually involves rest, hydration, and antibiotics.

Dysentery is caused by a bacterial infection, which can be spread through contaminated food and water. A person who has dysentery can pass the disease on to others if they do not wash their hands after using the bathroom.

Dysentery is caused by a variety of different viruses and bacteria, which can cause severe diarrhea and other symptoms. Risk factors include poor hygiene, exposure to sewage, drinking contaminated water or food, travel to developing countries, and certain medical conditions such as HIV/AIDS.

Dysentery is a condition that occurs when the lining of the intestine becomes inflamed. The main symptom of dysentery is bloody diarrhea, but other symptoms may include nausea, vomiting and fever. There are several things you can do to help prevent dysentery. One is to make sure that you wash your hands frequently, especially after going to the bathroom. It's also important to avoid touching your mouth with your hands. You should also avoid eating food that has been prepared in unsanitary conditions or that has not been cooked thoroughly.

Dementia is a general term that refers to a group of symptoms associated with memory loss and other cognitive abilities. A person who has dementia may have trouble remembering things, such as names, faces or recent events. He or she may also have problems with language and communication, including difficulty speaking, understanding words and expressing thoughts. Other symptoms can include changes in mood and behavior, such as irritability or depression, and difficulty performing daily activities, such as dressing or bathing.

Dementia is diagnosed through a combination of medical history and physical exam, blood tests, neuropsychological tests, brain imaging and possibly spinal fluid analysis. A person with dementia may have problems with memory, judgment, language, behavior or motor skills, such as walking or speaking. People with Alzheimer's disease usually experience the most severe symptoms, but there are many other types of dementia that can affect different areas of the brain.

The most common treatment for dementia is medication, but it is important to remember that medications do not cure dementia. It is also important to remember that there are many types of dementia, so a treatment plan will be different depending on the type of dementia that is being treated. Medications are usually prescribed by a doctor, and the person who has dementia may need to take the medication every day or only as needed. In some cases, people with dementia may also need to have their medications adjusted if they are experiencing side effects.

Dementia is a general term for loss of memory, language, problem-solving and other thinking skills that are severe enough to interfere with daily life. A person with dementia may have trouble remembering recent events or their own personal history. They may be unable to follow a conversation or complete everyday tasks such as cooking, paying bills or driving. Dementia is not a normal part of aging. The most common type is Alzheimer's disease, which makes up 60 to 80 percent of cases.

Dementia is a general term that refers to a decline in mental abilities, such as memory and cognition. A person with dementia will have difficulty remembering names or events, understanding instructions, performing basic tasks, communicating and recognizing familiar people. There are many causes of dementia, but the most common include Alzheimer's disease, vascular disease and frontotemporal dementia. Although it is not possible to prevent dementia, there are steps that can be taken to reduce the risk, including staying socially active, exercising regularly, eating a healthy diet, controlling high blood pressure, maintaining a healthy weight, avoiding smoking and getting plenty of sleep.

Dementia is a progressive, degenerative disease that causes changes in a person's cognition, behavior and functioning. In addition to these changes, people with dementia may also have difficulty performing daily activities such as dressing, bathing and cooking. These difficulties can make it challenging for individuals with dementia to live independently. There are many strategies that caregivers and health care providers can use to help manage the symptoms of dementia. These include encouraging exercise, providing assistance with activities of daily living, and using memory aids such as calendars and medication reminders.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils. The most common cause of tonsillitis is a viral infection, but bacterial infections can also be responsible for causing tonsillitis. Symptoms include sore throat, difficulty swallowing and fever. In some cases, tonsillitis may lead to more severe problems such as an abscess on the tonsil or even peritonsillar abscess.

Tonsillitis is often diagnosed with a medical history and physical exam. A health care professional will ask about the patient's symptoms and examine the throat, neck and ears. If tonsillitis is suspected, a swab of the tonsils can be taken to test for bacteria or other causes of the infection. In some cases, imaging tests, such as an x-ray or CT scan, may also be done.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils. In most cases, it is caused by a virus, and symptoms usually include sore throat, fever and swollen glands in the neck. In some cases, tonsillitis can be caused by bacteria or other organisms. People with tonsillitis will often experience severe pain when swallowing, and may also have difficulty opening their mouth wide or yawning. In severe cases, the tonsils can become so swollen that they obstruct breathing. Treatment for tonsillitis includes antibiotics and over-the-counter medications to relieve symptoms.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils and can cause severe pain, fever and difficulty swallowing. A child may also experience headaches or nausea. The symptoms usually go away within a few days, but if they last longer than a week, it's important to see a health care professional. In rare cases, tonsillitis can lead to serious complications, such as abscesses in the throat or neck, peritonsillar abscesses or cellulitis (a bacterial skin infection).

Tonsillitis is caused by a viral or bacterial infection. In most cases, tonsillitis is not preventable. However, there are things that people can do to reduce their risk of developing this condition. These include getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet and washing hands regularly.

Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils. A person with tonsillitis may have a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, earaches, fever and bad breath. There are many different causes of tonsillitis, including viruses, bacteria and allergies. People with tonsillitis should drink plenty of fluids, avoid alcohol, eat soft foods and gargle with salt water. Over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen can be used to reduce pain and fever.

Cellulitis is a bacterial infection that affects the skin and the tissue underneath it. Inflammation, redness, swelling, tenderness and pain are the most common symptoms. If the infection spreads to the lymph nodes in the groin or armpit, fever and chills may also be present. It is important to seek medical treatment if the infection does not clear up with antibiotics, if there are signs of sepsis (a blood infection) or if the person has diabetes or another underlying health condition.

Cellulitis is usually diagnosed based on the patient's symptoms, a medical history and physical examination. A doctor will often order blood tests to look for infections. The patient's skin will also be checked for signs of inflammation. If a bacterial infection is suspected, a culture may be taken from the site of infection and sent to a laboratory to confirm the diagnosis.

Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and tissue just underneath the skin. In many cases, antibiotics will be prescribed to treat this condition, but if it is severe or involves an area of the body where it is difficult to give an injection, such as the face, neck or hands, then surgery may be required.

Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and tissue just beneath the skin, which causes swelling, redness and pain. In severe cases, the infection can spread to the bloodstream, which can be life-threatening. The bacteria that cause cellulitis are typically transmitted through broken skin or open wounds, and they can also be transmitted by touching someone with cellulitis.

Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and tissue just underneath the skin, called the subcutaneous tissue. The bacteria that cause this condition can enter the body through an open wound or crack in the skin. People with diabetes have an increased risk of developing cellulitis because they have a higher chance of having an open wound on their feet. Other risk factors include poor blood circulation, obesity, heart disease, cancer, kidney failure, rheumatoid arthritis and liver disease.

Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection that can cause redness, warmth and swelling of the affected area. Lifestyle changes, including good hygiene habits, can help prevent cellulitis. Washing your hands often and thoroughly with soap and water can help prevent the spread of germs. This includes washing your hands before eating and after using the restroom. It is also important to keep cuts, scrapes and insect bites clean and covered.

The most common symptom of vasculitis is a fever, but it can also cause fatigue, muscle aches and pains, joint pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, diarrhea and rash. A doctor will diagnose vasculitis by taking a medical history, performing a physical examination and ordering tests, such as blood and urine tests.

The most common symptoms of vasculitis are headache, fever, fatigue and joint pain. Vascular disease can also cause inflammation of the skin, nerves or muscles. In some cases, vasculitis is associated with autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, Sjogren's syndrome and scleroderma. Diagnosis is typically made through a physical exam, medical history and blood tests.

The treatment options for vasculitis depend on the specific type of vasculitis a patient has and how severe it is. A doctor may recommend corticosteroids, such as prednisone or methylprednisolone, to help reduce inflammation in the blood vessels and decrease pain. In more severe cases, a person may need to take immunosuppressants, such as cyclophosphamide, azathioprine or mycophenolate mofetil, which can help suppress the immune system and prevent the body from attacking its own tissues.

The cause of vasculitis is unknown, but it is believed to be an autoimmune disorder. In some cases, it may be triggered by infections or allergies. It can also occur as a side effect of medications used to treat certain diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

Potential complications of vasculitis include: Kidney disease and failure, which can be caused by inflammation and scarring in the kidneys. Aortic aneurysm, which is a ballooning or bulging of the aorta, the major blood vessel that carries blood from the heart to the body. The aorta can be weakened by inflammation and can eventually rupture, leading to life-threatening bleeding. Aortic valve stenosis, a narrowing of the aortic valve, which is the valve between the left ventricle and the aorta. This can lead to high blood pressure and heart failure.

There is no cure for vasculitis, but there are treatments available to reduce the symptoms. A combination of medication and lifestyle changes may help manage the disease. Some of these lifestyle changes include stopping smoking, maintaining a healthy diet, limiting alcohol consumption, getting enough sleep, avoiding infections and taking care of any skin sores.

The most common symptom of liver cancer is abdominal pain, which can be felt in the upper right side. A person with liver cancer may also experience nausea and vomiting. Jaundice (yellowing of the skin) is another symptom, as is unexplained weight loss. It is important to note that many of these symptoms can also be caused by other conditions. For this reason, it is important to see a doctor if you experience any of these symptoms.

Liver cancer is usually diagnosed through a combination of imaging tests and biopsies. A liver biopsy involves removing a small piece of the liver to be examined under a microscope. This can be done through the skin or during surgery. Imaging tests include ultrasound, computed tomography (CT) scans, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and positron emission tomography (PET).

The most common treatment for liver cancer is surgery, and it is often the best option for people with early-stage liver cancer. A liver transplant may be an option for those who have had their entire liver removed or who are not healthy enough to undergo surgery. Other options include chemotherapy, radiation therapy and targeted drug therapy. These treatments are usually used in conjunction with surgery, but some patients may only need one of these therapies.

Liver cancer is a serious condition that can lead to a number of complications, including jaundice, bleeding and infections. In some cases, it can also spread to other parts of the body, leading to additional complications. People who have liver cancer should see their doctor as soon as possible so they can get treatment.

The most common risk factor for liver cancer is a viral infection, particularly hepatitis B and C. A person's age and gender also increase their risk of developing liver cancer. Heavy alcohol use, obesity and diabetes can all contribute to liver cancer as well. Other risk factors include cirrhosis, which is scarring of the liver, and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), which is fatty liver disease.

It is important to have regular checkups with your primary care physician, especially if you are at an increased risk for liver cancer. A healthy diet that includes plenty of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, lean protein and low-fat dairy products can also help reduce the risk of liver cancer. Additionally, it is important to limit alcohol consumption, as this can increase the risk of liver cancer. People who smoke should quit smoking, as this can also increase the risk.

The most common symptom of bronchitis is a cough that brings up mucus. Symptoms can be worse at night and may also include shortness of breath, chest pain and wheezing. In some cases, bronchitis can cause fever, chills and muscle aches. People with chronic bronchitis often experience these symptoms regularly, but they may not always have bronchitis.

Bronchitis is diagnosed through a physical examination, and by taking the patient's medical history. A health care provider will ask questions about symptoms, such as fever, coughing, sore throat, headaches and chest pain. The doctor will also listen to the lungs with a stethoscope.

There are several treatment options for bronchitis, which is inflammation of the airways in the lungs. The first line of treatment for acute bronchitis is to rest and drink plenty of fluids to help loosen mucus. Over-the-counter medications can also be used to reduce fever, relieve pain and decrease congestion. These include ibuprofen, acetaminophen and decongestants. If symptoms last more than three weeks or if there is a high fever, then antibiotics may be necessary. Antibiotics are usually prescribed by a doctor and will not work for viral bronchitis.

Bronchitis is inflammation of the air passages that carry air to the lungs. Bronchitis can be acute or chronic, and it is often caused by a viral infection. However, it can also be caused by bacteria, allergens or other irritants. Acute bronchitis usually goes away on its own, but chronic bronchitis can last for months and requires medical treatment. Symptoms include coughing, shortness of breath, wheezing, chest pain, sore throat, fever and fatigue.

The most common cause of bronchitis is infection, and people who smoke or have a weak immune system are at increased risk. Infections can be caused by viruses or bacteria, but most cases of acute bronchitis are viral. Certain medical conditions can also lead to chronic bronchitis, such as asthma, emphysema, cystic fibrosis, and allergies. People who have these conditions are at an increased risk of developing chronic bronchitis.

There are several lifestyle changes that can help to manage the symptoms of bronchitis. The most important change is to stop smoking, as smoking is a major risk factor for bronchitis. It is also important to avoid air pollution and irritants, such as dust and smoke, which can aggravate the symptoms of bronchitis. Drinking plenty of fluids and taking over-the-counter medications, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, can help to relieve some of the symptoms of bronchitis.

The most common symptom of a goitre is a swelling in the neck, which may cause difficulty breathing and swallowing. A goitre can also cause a person's voice to sound hoarse or deep. Other symptoms include enlargement of the thyroid gland, weight loss, fatigue, constipation, depression, dry skin and hair loss.
A goitre can be diagnosed with an ultrasound or CT scan. In some cases, it may be possible to diagnose a goitre based on the symptoms.

There are several treatment options for goitre, which is the enlargement of the thyroid gland. A doctor may prescribe antithyroid medications to reduce the size of the gland. Surgery to remove the thyroid gland is also an option, as is radioactive iodine therapy. In rare cases, a person with goitre may need to take hormone replacement therapy.

A goitre occurs when the thyroid gland becomes enlarged. The most common cause of goitre is iodine deficiency, which is often found in countries with limited access to iodized salt. Other causes include Hashimoto's disease, Graves' disease and certain medications.

The most common cause of goitre is an iodine deficiency, which can occur when the body does not receive enough iodine from food or supplements. A lack of iodine in the diet is the most common cause of goitre worldwide. Other causes include certain genetic conditions, such as hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism, as well as certain medications, including lithium, interferon and amiodarone. In rare cases, a goitre can be caused by cancer or a tumour in the thyroid gland.

The most important thing to do if you have a goitre is to eat a healthy diet. A balanced diet should include plenty of fruits and vegetables, as well as lean protein sources such as fish, poultry and beans. In addition, people with goitres should limit their intake of processed foods, such as refined grains, sugary drinks and fast food. Exercising regularly can also help reduce the size of a goitre.

The main symptoms of cardiomyopathy are shortness of breath, fatigue, swelling in the ankles and feet, and abnormal heart rhythms. There may also be chest pain, palpitations, or fainting spells. Cardiomyopathy is a serious disease that can lead to heart failure. A person with cardiomyopathy will need to be monitored closely by their doctor and may need medications, surgery, or a pacemaker. In some cases, there are no symptoms at all. People with cardiomyopathy should make healthy lifestyle changes. These include eating a healthy diet that is low in sodium, caffeine and alcohol, as well as limiting their intake of red meat and sugar. They should also exercise regularly and get regular checkups.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease that causes inflammation in the joints, leading to pain and stiffness. In addition to these symptoms, osteoarthritis can also cause swelling, redness, warmth and limited range of motion in the affected joints. The most common symptoms occur in the knees, hands, hips and spine. People who have osteoarthritis often have a hard time performing activities that require repetitive movements, such as lifting, climbing stairs or getting out of a chair.

Osteoarthritis, the most common form of arthritis, can be diagnosed through a physical exam and x-rays. A physician will take a medical history, which includes questions about your joint pain and any family history of arthritis. The doctor will also perform a physical examination to assess the range of motion of the affected joints and whether there is tenderness in the joint. X-rays are usually performed to determine if the joint is inflamed or damaged.

There is no cure for osteoarthritis, but there are a number of treatments available to help relieve symptoms. A combination of rest and physical therapy can often help reduce the pain associated with arthritis. Anti-inflammatory medications can also be used to help reduce swelling in the joints, and they can be prescribed by a doctor. In addition, corticosteroids may also be prescribed to help reduce the inflammation caused by osteoarthritis. Surgery may be an option for people whose pain is severe and does not respond to other treatments.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease that causes the cartilage in the joint to deteriorate. In most cases, this condition develops gradually over many years and often affects the knee, hip, spine or hand. When the cartilage in a joint wears down, the bones rub together, causing pain, swelling, stiffness and reduced range of motion. This condition can lead to disability if left untreated.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease that causes the cartilage in the joint to deteriorate. Risk factors include obesity, injury or trauma to the joint, age and genetics. People who have a family history of osteoarthritis are more likely to develop it. Other risk factors include smoking and being physically active.

The symptoms of Autism spectrum disorder vary from person to person, but typically include a lack of social interaction, communication problems and repetitive behaviors. A child with autism may have trouble understanding nonverbal communication, such as gestures and facial expressions, or they may not be able to speak at all. They may also have difficulty interacting with others, and they may engage in repetitive behaviors like hand-flapping or rocking back and forth.

The most common symptoms of autism are delays in speech and language, social skills, and cognitive development. A child may also exhibit unusual behaviors or have sensory issues such as over-sensitivity to certain noises or textures. If a child has these symptoms and there is a strong family history of autism, it is important to talk with the child's pediatrician.

There is no cure for Autism spectrum disorder, but there are several different treatment options. A combination of behavioral therapy and medications may be used to help improve communication skills and social interaction skills. Behavioral therapy includes speech therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. Medications that may be prescribed include anti-psychotic drugs, antidepressants and stimulant drugs.

Autism spectrum disorder is a developmental disability that can occur in children, teenagers and even adults. The symptoms of ASD vary greatly from person to person. Some people may have only mild symptoms while others have more severe symptoms that affect all aspects of their life. The most common signs of ASD are social impairment, communication problems and repetitive behaviors.

There is no single cause of Autism spectrum disorder, and it is not clear what causes the condition. Risk factors may include genetic factors, premature birth, low birth weight, having a brother or sister with ASD and exposure to viral infections during pregnancy.

Social skills are the skills needed to communicate and interact with others. Children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) often have difficulty with social skills, which may include not knowing what to say or do when talking to someone, having a hard time reading nonverbal cues like facial expressions and tone of voice, and having trouble maintaining conversations. Fortunately, there are many things parents can do to help improve their child's social skills.

Acne is a skin condition that occurs when the sebaceous glands in the skin become clogged, forming blackheads and whiteheads. A number of factors can lead to acne, including hormones, diet and genetics. Hormonal changes during puberty are the most common cause of acne, but it can occur at any age. Certain foods can trigger acne, such as greasy or fried foods, chocolate, processed meats and dairy products. Genetics also play a role in whether someone develops acne.

Acne is a skin condition that can cause pimples and blackheads. It is caused by overactive oil glands, bacteria and dead skin cells. Treatment options include topical medications, oral medications and laser therapy. Topical medications are usually used first, but they may not be effective in treating severe cases of acne. Oral medications may be used in combination with topical medications. Laser therapy is sometimes used to treat severe cases of acne.

There are several different types of acne, including blackheads, whiteheads, pustules, nodules and cysts. A person with acne often has a combination of these types. Blackheads occur when dead skin cells and sebum become trapped in the pores of the skin, forming a small bump. Whiteheads are similar to blackheads, but the pores do not open. Instead, they remain closed, which causes the oil to build up inside. Pustules are larger than whiteheads and contain pus. Nodules occur when the body reacts to the infection and tries to heal it by forming a hard lump under the skin. Cysts occur when a nodule becomes infected and forms a fluid-filled pocket beneath the skin.

Diet is one of the biggest factors that can contribute to acne. A diet high in fat and cholesterol may increase inflammation and clog pores, which can lead to acne breakouts. Foods high in carbohydrates, such as bread and pasta, are also thought to trigger acne, because they cause an increase in insulin levels in the body. People who have acne should avoid eating a lot of junk food, as it may make their acne worse.

Hygiene is important when it comes to acne, but it is not the only factor. A combination of factors, including diet, stress and genetics, all play a role in causing acne. People with oily skin are more likely to develop acne, but anyone can have acne, regardless of their skin type. Acne can be caused by hormones, which increase sebum production in the skin. This can lead to clogged pores, which cause inflammation and bacteria growth. Washing your face twice a day can help reduce oil production. However, washing too frequently can irritate your skin and make acne worse. It is also important to avoid picking or squeezing pimples, as this can lead to scarring.

Acne is a chronic condition, and it can take many years to clear. In most cases, acne goes away on its own over time. However, if acne persists or gets worse, it may be necessary to see a doctor. Some people with severe acne may need prescription medication or other treatments. It's also important to note that acne can leave scars.

The most common symptom of sickle cell disease is anemia, which is a condition in which the red blood cells do not carry enough oxygen throughout the body. Sickle cell disease is also characterized by episodes of pain called "sickle cell crisis" or "sickle cell pain crises." These episodes are usually caused by blocked blood vessels. Other symptoms of sickle cell disease include fatigue, shortness of breath and yellowing of the skin (jaundice).

The most common way to diagnose sickle cell disease is with a blood test. Sickle cell disease is an inherited disorder, and children who have it typically show symptoms by the age of 5. If a child has a family member who has sickle cell disease, then there is a 1 in 4 chance that the child will also have this condition.

There is no cure for sickle cell disease, but there are several treatment options to help manage the condition. Sickle cell patients may be treated with antibiotics to prevent infections and pain medications to help reduce the pain that often occurs. In addition, some people may undergo blood transfusions, which involves receiving donated blood. Blood transfusions can be helpful in relieving the symptoms of sickle cell disease and improving the quality of life for people who have this condition.

Sickle cell disease is a group of inherited disorders that cause red blood cells to be misshapen, and this causes them to stick together, block blood vessels and break apart. The most common complications include anemia, painful episodes, infections, organ damage and stroke. Symptoms vary from person to person. People with sickle cell disease often have painful episodes, which may require hospitalization. Other symptoms may include fatigue, shortness of breath, yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice), fever, joint pain and swelling, and delayed growth and puberty.

The most common risk factor for inheriting sickle cell disease is having a family member who has sickle cell disease. Sickle cell disease is an inherited blood disorder that causes red blood cells to become abnormally shaped. These cells are not able to carry oxygen effectively throughout the body, which can lead to serious health problems. People with sickle cell disease often have painful crises, in which their bone marrow cannot produce enough red blood cells to meet the body's needs.

The most important thing to do if you have sickle cell disease is to avoid infections and other triggers, such as cold weather. Sickle cell disease is a lifelong condition that requires ongoing care, which may include medications to help reduce pain, prevent complications and control anemia. People with sickle cell disease should also be vaccinated against pneumococcal disease and meningococcal disease, since these bacteria can cause serious infections.

Common symptoms of ovarian cancer include abdominal or pelvic pain, bloating and pressure in the pelvis, weight gain, changes in bowel habits, and frequent urination. A diagnosis of ovarian cancer is usually made after a physical exam, a pelvic exam, blood tests, imaging tests, such as ultrasound or CT scan, and a biopsy of the tumor.

Ovarian cancer is often diagnosed through a combination of tests and procedures, including an ultrasound, blood tests and a pelvic exam. A doctor may also perform a laparoscopy to see inside the abdomen. In this procedure, the doctor will make small incisions in the abdomen and insert a thin tube with a camera on the end into the abdomen. This allows the doctor to look for signs of cancer.

The most common treatment options for ovarian cancer include surgery and chemotherapy. A complete hysterectomy is usually performed to remove the uterus, cervix and fallopian tubes, while a total abdominal hysterectomy is used to remove the uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and surrounding lymph nodes. The type of surgery will depend on the stage of the cancer, as well as whether or not the patient has undergone any previous surgeries. After surgery, chemotherapy may be recommended to kill any remaining cancer cells.

Ovarian cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the cells of the ovary. The most common symptoms include abdominal swelling and bloating, weight gain or loss, increased thirst, nausea, vomiting, constipation, frequent urination, fatigue and pain in the pelvis or abdomen. In advanced stages, patients may experience pain during sex and menstrual cramps. Other symptoms may include bleeding from the rectum or vagina.

Ovarian cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the cells of the ovary. Risk factors include a personal history of breast or endometrial cancer, a family history of ovarian cancer, obesity, infertility and not being pregnant by age 30. Other risk factors include use of hormone therapy after menopause, taking birth control pills for five years or more and using talcum powder in the genital area.

There is no sure way to prevent ovarian cancer, but it is possible to reduce the risk of developing this disease. A woman's lifetime risk of developing ovarian cancer is about 1 in 75. The most important thing that a woman can do to lower her risk of ovarian cancer is to have regular pelvic exams and Pap smears, which can detect changes in the cervix and vagina, as well as abnormal cells on the surface of the ovary. Women should also talk to their health care provider about having an ultrasound of the ovaries every year.

The most common symptoms of the flu include fever, cough, headache, muscle aches, sore throat and fatigue. A runny or stuffy nose may also occur. In severe cases, people can develop pneumonia or even death. Some people may have diarrhea or vomiting as well.

Influenza is a virus that is spread by coughing, sneezing and touching surfaces contaminated with the virus. A person can get the flu if they come into contact with someone who has the virus. People who are infected with the virus can spread it to others for about seven days after becoming sick, but people may be able to spread the virus even when they feel better and do not have any symptoms.

The most common treatment for influenza is rest and fluids. A person with the flu should stay home to avoid spreading the virus. People with the flu may also be prescribed antiviral medications, which work by stopping the virus from growing in the body. These medications can help shorten the length of a person's illness and decrease the risk of complications, such as pneumonia.

There are two main types of influenza vaccine, and they are both recommended for everyone 6 months of age and older: Inactivated flu vaccine. The most common type of flu vaccine contains an inactive virus that is grown in eggs. It is approved for use in people who are at least 6 months old and is given by injection. This is the vaccine that is typically used in health care settings, including long-term care facilities, hospitals and doctors' offices. The nasal spray flu vaccine contains a live, weakened form of the virus and is approved for use in healthy people ages 2 to 49 years. It is not recommended for pregnant women or people with certain medical conditions.

The elderly, young children and people with chronic health conditions such as diabetes, asthma, heart disease, cancer or HIV/AIDS are more likely to have complications from influenza.
How is the flu diagnosed? Flu can be diagnosed by a physician using a swab test, which takes a sample of mucus from the back of the nose and throat and tests it for the presence of influenza virus.

It is recommended to get vaccinated every year, as this is the best way to protect against influenza. A flu shot should be given to anyone over 6 months old. The vaccine can also be given to pregnant women. People who are at high risk for complications from the flu, such as those with chronic lung disease or heart disease, should also receive a flu shot.

Prostatitis is inflammation of the prostate gland, which is a small organ located below the bladder in men. The most common symptom is pain and discomfort in the pelvic area, which may be constant or come and go. Other symptoms can include frequent urination, difficulty urinating, blood in the urine and painful ejaculation.

Prostatitis is diagnosed through a combination of medical history and physical examination. A medical professional will perform a digital rectal examination to feel the prostate gland for tenderness, swelling or other abnormalities. Other tests that may be used to diagnose prostatitis include urine analysis, blood tests, ultrasound, CT scan or MRI.

Prostatitis is inflammation of the prostate gland and it can be caused by infections, benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlargement of the prostate) or injuries. In many cases, treatment will focus on treating the underlying cause, such as bacteria, viruses or other organisms. Antibiotics are often prescribed to treat prostatitis caused by infection. Other treatments may include surgery, catheterization or transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), which involves using an instrument to remove part of the prostate.

Prostatitis is an inflammation of the prostate that can cause pain, urinary problems and other symptoms. In most cases, it is not a chronic condition and does not require treatment. However, in some cases, it may be necessary to treat the condition with medications or surgery.

Prostatitis is a condition that can affect men of any age, but it is most common in men between the ages of 40 and 50. In younger men, the condition is usually caused by an infection, such as a urinary tract infection or sexually transmitted disease. In older men, prostatitis may be caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia, which is an enlargement of the prostate gland.

Prostatitis is inflammation of the prostate gland and it can be caused by an infection, an injury to the prostate or other causes. In many cases, there is no known cause for prostatitis. If the patient has had symptoms for more than six weeks and there is no clear cause, the condition is considered chronic. Chronic prostatitis can be treated with antibiotics and pain medications, but if these treatments are unsuccessful, surgery may be necessary.

Mumps is a viral infection caused by the mumps virus, which is spread through saliva. The main symptom of mumps is swollen parotid glands (salivary glands) on both sides of the face. Other symptoms include fever, headache and muscle aches. Some people will also have a cough, sore throat or runny nose. People who have had chickenpox or measles are already immune to mumps.

Mumps is spread through saliva, and it can be transmitted by coughing, sneezing, sharing food or drinks and touching surfaces that have been contaminated with saliva. A person can become infected if they come in contact with someone who is sick and has mumps, or if they are bitten by a mosquito that has bitten an infected person.

Mumps is a viral infection that can cause fever, headache, muscle aches and fatigue. A person with mumps may also have swollen salivary glands on both sides of the neck. These glands will be tender to touch, but there will not be any pus draining from them. The infection usually lasts between seven and 10 days and people typically recover without any problems. Complications of mumps are uncommon, but can include meningitis, deafness and inflammation of the testicles or ovaries.

Mumps is a contagious virus that spreads through contact with the saliva or nasal secretions of an infected person. A person is most contagious when they are in the early stages of the illness, which lasts about 10 to 25 days. To prevent the spread of mumps, avoid close contact with people who have symptoms and do not share food or drinks with someone who is sick. People who have mumps should avoid contact with others until they are no longer contagious.

Mumps is a viral infection that can cause fever and swelling of the salivary glands, which can be quite painful. A doctor may recommend over-the-counter medications to ease the pain, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen. They may also suggest taking anti-inflammatory drugs. If the patient has an earache, they may prescribe antibiotics. There is no specific treatment for mumps, but people with mumps should avoid contact with others to prevent spreading the virus.

Mumps is usually diagnosed by a health care provider through a physical examination. A person may have swelling of the parotid gland, which is located in the cheek on either side of the face, and this is the most common symptom. Other symptoms can include fever, headache, muscle aches, nausea and fatigue.

Schizoaffective disorder is a mental health condition that causes symptoms of both schizophrenia and a mood disorder, such as bipolar disorder or major depression. A person who has this disorder will experience psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations or delusions, but also will have mood symptoms. Symptoms can vary depending on which mood symptom is more prevalent, but in general, these symptoms include changes in behavior, sleep patterns, energy levels and appetite, and they can last for months or even years.

Schizoaffective disorder can be difficult to diagnose because it often mimics other conditions. A psychiatrist will conduct a comprehensive evaluation that includes a physical examination, interview and medical history, as well as laboratory tests. The patient's family members may also be interviewed. In addition, the psychiatrist will use a structured diagnostic interview, such as the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV (SCID), to confirm a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder.

Schizoaffective disorder can be treated with a combination of medication, psychotherapy and family support. A common medication used to treat schizoaffective disorder is an antipsychotic called risperidone (Risperdal), which is available as a tablet or liquid. Another option is clozapine, which is only available by prescription and must be taken in conjunction with other medications. Other antipsychotics that may be prescribed include olanzapine (Zyprexa), quetiapine (Seroquel) and ziprasidone (Geodon). In addition, antidepressants are often prescribed to help treat the depression associated with this condition.

Schizoaffective disorder is a mental health condition that causes symptoms of both schizophrenia and depression. In order to be diagnosed with this condition, a person must experience psychotic symptoms (such as hallucinations or delusions), as well as mood symptoms (such as depressed mood or irritability). The severity of these symptoms can vary depending on the individual. People who have schizoaffective disorder may also experience symptoms of mania, which are similar to those experienced by people with bipolar disorder.

Schizoaffective disorder can cause a variety of symptoms, including hallucinations and delusions. The severity of these symptoms will depend on the type of schizoaffective disorder a person has. For example, paranoid schizophrenia causes more severe symptoms than bipolar schizoaffective disorder, which is characterized by manic episodes. People with this condition often experience psychosis and depression at the same time, which can make it difficult to manage everyday life.

Schizoaffective disorder is a mental health condition that causes symptoms of both schizophrenia and a mood disorder, such as bipolar disorder. A person with this condition will experience episodes of mania or depression, along with hallucinations and delusions. Medication is often used to treat schizoaffective disorder, as well as psychosis and other symptoms. Antipsychotic drugs are the most commonly used medications for this condition.

Sinusitis is inflammation of the sinuses, which are hollow cavities in the skull behind the nose. Sinusitis occurs when these cavities become infected or filled with mucus, leading to symptoms like congestion, headache, facial pain and pressure, fever, cough, postnasal drip and fatigue. It can be caused by allergies, infections or structural abnormalities in the nasal passages, such as a deviated septum.

Sinusitis is inflammation of the sinuses, which are hollow cavities in the skull behind the nose. The most common symptom of sinusitis is a stuffy or runny nose, but it can also cause pain and tenderness around the eyes, cheeks and forehead, as well as a cough, sore throat, fever, headache and fatigue. People who have had sinusitis before may experience these symptoms more severely than people who have not.

Sinusitis is inflammation of the sinuses, and it is often treated with antibiotics. A person may also use over-the-counter medications to help relieve symptoms. In addition, some people find that certain lifestyle changes can be helpful for treating sinusitis. These include drinking plenty of fluids, eating a healthy diet, avoiding smoking, and getting plenty of rest. It's important to talk to a doctor before making any major lifestyle changes, as they may have recommendations on how to manage the condition.

Sinusitis is inflammation of the sinuses, and it is often caused by a viral infection. Risk factors include having allergies or asthma, smoking, exposure to secondhand smoke, nasal polyps, nasal obstruction, dental infections, chronic sinusitis, nasal tumors and immunodeficiency. People with certain medical conditions, such as cystic fibrosis and HIV, are also at increased risk.

Sinusitis is inflammation of the sinuses, and it is often accompanied by a fever. A person with sinusitis may experience symptoms for anywhere from two to eight weeks, depending on how severe the condition is. In some cases, it can take longer to recover. The best way to treat sinusitis is to see a doctor, who can prescribe antibiotics or other medications to help relieve symptoms.

Sinusitis is inflammation of the sinuses, and it is often treated with antibiotics, decongestants or nasal sprays. A doctor may also recommend saline irrigation to wash out mucus from the sinuses. If these treatments do not work, a patient may be referred to an ear, nose and throat (ENT) specialist.

Pernicious anemia is a type of anemia in which the body does not have enough healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen throughout the body. In people with pernicious anemia, the stomach cannot absorb vitamin B-12, a nutrient that helps form red blood cells. The most common symptoms of pernicious anemia include fatigue, pale skin and weakness. People with this condition may also experience difficulty walking, numbness in the legs or feet, dizziness, depression and irritability.

Pernicious anemia is diagnosed with a blood test that checks the levels of vitamin B12 in the blood. A person who has low levels of vitamin B12 may have symptoms such as fatigue, weakness and numbness. If these symptoms are present, a doctor will usually perform a blood test to determine if the person has pernicious anemia.

Pernicious anemia is a type of anemia, or low red blood cell count, that occurs when the stomach cannot make enough intrinsic factor. The body needs intrinsic factor to absorb vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 is needed for healthy blood and nervous system function. People with pernicious anemia can experience symptoms such as fatigue, pale skin and weakness. Treatment includes replacing vitamin B12, which is done through injections or supplements.

Pernicious anemia is a type of anemia in which the body is unable to make enough healthy red blood cells. In addition, people with pernicious anemia have a vitamin B-12 deficiency. People who are at risk for developing this condition include those who have had gastric bypass surgery, have a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and those who have had long-term use of certain drugs that block the absorption of vitamin B-12. The most common symptom of pernicious anemia is fatigue, but it may also cause other symptoms such as pale skin, weakness, diarrhea, depression and headaches.

Pernicious anemia is a type of anemia, or low red blood cell count, that occurs when the stomach cannot properly absorb vitamin B12. In many cases, this is because of a deficiency in intrinsic factor, which is a protein that helps the body absorb vitamin B12 from food. The most common cause of pernicious anemia is autoimmune destruction of the parietal cells, which produce intrinsic factor. Other causes can include surgical removal of the stomach, bacterial overgrowth and other conditions that lead to inflammation in the stomach.

Pernicious anemia is a type of anemia, or low red blood cell count, caused by a lack of vitamin B12. A person with pernicious anemia may experience fatigue, pale skin, dizziness and nerve damage. Treatment for pernicious anemia involves taking supplemental vitamin B12. Lifestyle changes can also be helpful. These include avoiding alcohol and caffeine and eating a healthy diet that includes leafy green vegetables, fish, poultry and whole grains.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia, or BPH, is a condition in which the prostate gland enlarges as men age. The prostate gland surrounds the urethra, which carries urine from the bladder out of the body. As the prostate gets bigger, it may squeeze the urethra and cause problems with urination. Symptoms include having to urinate often, especially at night; feeling the need to urinate urgently, even when the bladder is not full; having difficulty starting urination; and leaking urine.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia, or BPH, is a condition in which the prostate gland enlarges, causing it to press on the urethra. The symptoms of BPH vary from mild to severe and include: Frequent urination, especially at night; Difficulty starting the urinary stream; A weak urine stream; Urinary hesitancy (taking longer than usual to start urinating); Incomplete emptying of the bladder; Urinary retention (inability to completely empty the bladder); Nocturia (frequent nighttime urination); and Dribbling of urine.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia, or BPH, is diagnosed with a medical history and physical examination. A urine test may be performed to look for blood in the urine, which would indicate an enlarged prostate gland. The doctor will also check for any abnormalities in the prostate gland during the physical examination. If there are any signs of prostate cancer, further testing will be done to rule out this condition.

There are several treatments available for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is the noncancerous enlargement of the prostate gland. BPH can lead to problems with urination, including difficulty starting and stopping urine flow. Treatment depends on the severity of the symptoms. For mild cases, simple lifestyle changes can help, such as drinking less fluid and reducing caffeine intake. If these measures don't work, medications may be prescribed. Medications used for BPH include alpha blockers, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, diuretics and antimuscarinic drugs. For more severe cases, a surgical procedure called transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is recommended. Benign prostatic hyperplasia can lead to a number of complications, including urinary retention and incontinence. In some cases, benign prostatic hyperplasia may cause the bladder to become inflamed or infected. If left untreated, benign prostatic hyperplasia may lead to kidney failure or other serious problems.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia, or BPH, is a condition that affects the prostate. The prostate is a small gland located in front of the rectum and just below the bladder. In men with BPH, the prostate grows larger, causing the urethra (the tube through which urine passes) to narrow. This can lead to symptoms such as difficulty starting the flow of urine, frequent urination, urgency to urinate, getting up at night to urinate, dribbling after urinating and painful urination.

The most common symptom of thyroid cancer is a lump or mass in the neck. A patient may also experience difficulty swallowing, hoarseness or a sore throat that does not go away, trouble breathing and weight loss. Some patients with thyroid cancer have no symptoms at all, so it is important to be screened regularly by a doctor, especially if there is a family history of thyroid disease.

The most common symptom of thyroid cancer is a lump or mass in the neck. A doctor may be able to feel a thyroid nodule during an examination of the neck, but imaging tests are usually necessary to determine if a nodule is benign (noncancerous) or malignant (cancerous). An ultrasound can be used to identify any suspicious areas and guide a fine-needle aspiration, which removes a sample of cells from a thyroid nodule. This sample can then be analyzed for signs of cancer.

The most common treatment for thyroid cancer is surgery, and it is often followed by radioactive iodine ablation to remove any remaining cancer cells. In some cases, radioactive iodine may be given before surgery to shrink the tumor. If the tumor is too large for surgery or if there are multiple tumors in the thyroid, the patient may receive radiation therapy instead of surgery.

The thyroid is a butterfly-shaped gland located in the base of the neck, just below the Adam's apple. It produces hormones that regulate many vital functions, including metabolism, heart rate and blood pressure. Thyroid problems can lead to a variety of health problems, including obesity, high cholesterol, infertility, hair loss and depression.

Risk factors for developing thyroid cancer include age, sex and family history. Caucasian women have a slightly higher risk of developing the disease than men. The risk of thyroid cancer is also higher in patients who have had radiation therapy to the neck or head. Other risk factors include exposure to radioactive iodine, such as in the case of patients with an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism), and exposure to certain chemicals, including perchlorate.

It is important to have regular checkups with your doctor after being diagnosed with thyroid cancer. A yearly physical and a blood test for thyroid hormone levels are usually recommended. Lifestyle changes, such as avoiding alcohol and caffeine, exercising regularly and eating a healthy diet, are also recommended. These can help reduce the risk of recurrence.

Hives are itchy, red, raised bumps on the skin that often appear suddenly. The cause of hives is unknown, but they can be triggered by food allergies, medications or insect stings. In some cases, hives may be a symptom of an underlying medical condition.

Hives are itchy, red, raised bumps on the skin that often appear in clusters and can vary in size. The most common cause is an allergic reaction to a food or medication, although there are many other possible causes. Symptoms include itching, burning and stinging, and they may also be accompanied by swelling of the face and throat, wheezing and shortness of breath.

Hives are usually treated with over-the-counter antihistamines, such as Benadryl (diphenhydramine) or Claritin (loratadine). These medications work by blocking the effects of histamine, which is a chemical that causes itching and swelling. A doctor may prescribe a stronger antihistamine if symptoms don't improve after taking an over-the-counter medicine for several days.

Hives are itchy, red welts on the skin that may be caused by a variety of triggers, including stress. Hives may occur anywhere on the body but are most often found on the neck, chest and back. They typically appear as small, raised bumps that can vary in size from 1/4 inch to 3 inches in diameter. Hives can last for hours or even days, and some people experience recurrent outbreaks. The cause of hives is unknown, but they are thought to be an allergic reaction. Stress can trigger hives, so people who are prone to stress should avoid situations that might cause them to feel anxious or worried.

Hives caused by allergies can last anywhere from a few hours to a few weeks. A single episode of hives usually resolves within 24 hours, but some people have chronic hives that last several weeks or longer. The most important thing is to identify and avoid the triggers that cause hives. See your doctor if hives do not improve or last longer than a week because this may be a sign of a more serious condition.
It is important to avoid triggers of hives, which include foods, medications and allergens. Avoiding triggers will help to prevent the development of hives and keep them from coming back.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral illness that affects people in tropical and subtropical regions. A person with dengue fever will have fever, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, vomiting, diarrhea and sometimes a skin rash. The virus can cause hemorrhaging, bleeding from the gums and nose and internal bleeding. There is no vaccine available for dengue fever, but it can be prevented by using mosquito repellent and wearing long sleeves and pants when outdoors in areas where dengue is common.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral illness that causes symptoms such as fever, headache, nausea and vomiting. A person can get dengue fever if he or she is bitten by an infected mosquito. The mosquitoes that spread the virus are known as Aedes mosquitoes, which bite during the daytime. The most common type of dengue fever, dengue hemorrhagic fever, occurs when a person gets the disease for a second time. This type of dengue fever is more serious than the first infection, and it is possible to die from dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral illness that causes fever, rash and flu-like symptoms. A severe form of the disease called dengue hemorrhagic fever can be fatal if not treated. Treatment focuses on managing the symptoms and preventing dehydration. There is no specific treatment for dengue fever. People who have had dengue fever in the past should avoid areas with mosquitoes to prevent reinfection.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne illness, so the best way to prevent it is to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes. Avoiding mosquito bites means using insect repellent and wearing long sleeves and pants in areas where mosquitoes are common. In addition, people should empty standing water from outdoor containers and ensure that window screens are intact. People who have been infected with dengue fever can also help prevent others from getting sick by staying at home for 5 to 7 days after their symptoms begin and avoiding contact with others.

Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral illness that causes symptoms such as fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, and nausea. A more severe form of the disease called dengue hemorrhagic fever can cause bleeding from the nose or gums, low blood pressure, liver damage, and shock. The risk of dengue fever increases with age and is highest in children under 10 years old. People who have been infected with dengue virus once are at higher risk for getting it again, and there is no vaccine to prevent the infection.

The symptoms of dengue fever can last up to 10 days, and most people will feel better after about a week. People who have been infected with dengue fever should take it easy for several weeks to allow their immune system to recover.

The most common symptom of scleroderma is hardening and tightening of the skin. Scleroderma is a chronic autoimmune disease that causes the body to produce too much collagen, which leads to stiffness in the skin, muscles, blood vessels and internal organs. People with scleroderma may also experience other symptoms, such as pain, swelling, weakness, fatigue and digestive problems. In severe cases, the condition can cause damage to the heart, lungs, kidneys and gastrointestinal tract.

Scleroderma is a condition that can be difficult to diagnose, as the symptoms may resemble those of many other conditions. A patient may be referred to a rheumatologist or dermatologist who will take a detailed medical history and perform a physical examination to rule out other causes of the symptoms. The doctor will also order lab tests, including blood tests, skin biopsy and nail fold capillaroscopy. In some cases, the doctor may also order imaging studies, such as an X-ray or ultrasound.

There is no cure for scleroderma, but there are a number of treatment options. Scleroderma is a chronic disease that affects the connective tissue, or collagen, in the skin and internal organs. Symptoms include thickening and tightening of the skin, which can lead to painful swelling in the fingers, toes and face, as well as digestive problems. Other symptoms may include joint pain, muscle weakness, fatigue, high blood pressure, heartburn and gastrointestinal issues. The most common symptom of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is tingling, numbness and weakness in the feet that can progress to the hands, arms, legs, neck and face. Affected individuals may also experience a loss of deep tendon reflexes, problems with coordination, and muscle atrophy. Some people also develop blurry vision or drooping eyelids. In severe cases, the GBS can lead to paralysis, respiratory distress and difficulty swallowing.

The most important treatment for Guillain–Barré syndrome is immunoglobulin, which helps to decrease inflammation and may help prevent muscle weakness. Epilepsy is a condition that causes seizures. A seizure is a sudden, uncontrolled movement or change in behavior caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain.
